section_one.paragraph_one: Experience Sri Lanka’s most elusive wildlife in the vast seclusion of Wilpattu National Park. Occupying a vast swathe of land bordering the copper-sand beaches of the north west coast, the ancient ruins of the Cultural

section_one.paragraph_two: Triangle and the Northern Province, this is Sri Lanka’s largest and oldest game reserve.

section_one.paragraph_three: Home to myriad endemic species, the park fosters sensational bird life, Asian Elephants, Sri Lankan Leopards, Sri Lankan Sloth Bears.

section_two.paragrpah_one: While Wilpattu was first designated a wildlife sanctuary as far back as 1905, it wasn’t until February 1938 that this 13,500-hectare park was elevated to national park status. Yet, its story begins much earlier than this

section_two.paragraph_two: The copper shoreline of the reserve, specifically at Kudiramalai, a rocky promontory, is widely believed to have been the landing spot of the Indian Prince Vijaya in the 5th century BC. He married Princess Kuveni of Sri Lanka,

section_two.papagrpah_three: and together they established the Sinhalese race. The region’s alternative name – Thambapanni or the ‘colour of copper’ – came about due to the reddish colour of the sand that stained the hands and feet of Prince Vijaya and his 700-odd followers when they came ashore. The ruins of Kuveni’s palace is just one of 68 archeological sites within Wilpattu National Park.

section_three.heading: WHAT WILDLIFE CAN YOU SEE IN WILPATTU?

section_three.paragraph_one: Wilpattu National Park is home to Sri Lanka’s most exciting, longed-to-see wildlife. These include the elusive Sri Lankan leopard, the Asian Elephant and the Sri Lankan Sloth Bear alongside a supporting cast of spotted and sambar deer, crocodiles, mongooses and water buffalo.

section_three.paragraph_two: Leopard sightings are amongst the best in the country despite the reserve having a much less dense leopard population than Yala National Park.

section_three.paragraph_three: The aquatic features of the park also make this one of Sri Lanka’s best places for bird watching – some of the endemics include the Ceylon grey hornbill, the Ceylon Prakeet and the Red-backed woodpecker.

section_three.paragraph_four: You may also spy the brownish chicken-like Sri Lankan Jungle fowl, Sri Lanka’s national bird.
